headline.main: Old Age in America, by the Numbers

docs.abstract: A new report paints a statistical portrait of aging Americans.
docs.lead_paragraph: The population of older Americans is growing faster than ever and living longer than ever, but not as long as in much of Europe and elsewhere in the developed world, according to "Older Americans 2010: Key Indicators of Well-Being," a report compiled by 15 federal agencies.
docs.snippet: A new report paints a statistical portrait of aging Americans.

headline.print_headline: Home Birth May Add Some Risks
headline.main: Home Birth May Add a Wrinkle

docs.lead_paragraph: A review of studies has found that planned home birth holds more than twice the risk for death from the ages of 1 week to 1 month compared with planned hospital birth.
docs.snippet: A review of studies has found that planned home birth holds more than twice the risk for death from the ages of 1 week to 1 month compared with planned hospital birth.

docs.lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (13); 11 P.M. (49) EL GENERAL (2009) In 1978 Alicia Calles began recording her memoirs with the hope of writing a book about her father, Plutarco Elías Calles, above, a general in the Mexican Revolution and the president of Mexico from 1924 to 1928, who left a controversial legacy. He founded the National Revolutionary Party, which, as the subsequent Institutional Revolutionary Party, governed the country for more than 70 years. He also fiercely oppressed Roman Catholics. Eventually Alicia Calles's granddaughter, Natalia Almada, inherited the tapes, creating not only a snapshot of her family's past but also a backdrop against which to better understand modern Mexico in this centennial year of the start of the revolution in 1910. The documentary, presented here by ''P.O.V.,'' earned Ms. Almada the directing award and a nomination for the grand jury prize at the 2009 Sundance Film Festival. 8 P.M. (NBC) LOSING IT WITH JILLIAN Jillian Michaels heads to Florida in this season finale, where she gives the Alvarez family a big dose of tough love. David Jr., 9, is drastically overweight and prediabetic. What's worse, as far as Ms. Michaels is concerned, is that David Sr., whose own obesity has led to serious health complications, doesn't see anything wrong with his weight -- or his son's.
docs.snippet: 10 P.M. (13); 11 P.M. (49) EL GENERAL (2009) In 1978 Alicia Calles began recording her memoirs with the hope of writing a book about her father, Plutarco Elías Calles, above, a general in the Mexican Revolution and the president of Mexico from 1924...

headline.print_headline: Oh, Look, More Glimmers of Good News

docs.lead_paragraph: Times are dreary — in the economy, in the national mood, overseas. Isn’t anything positive happening? We tried hard to find better news out there.
docs.snippet: Times are dreary — in the economy, in the national mood, overseas. Isn’t anything positive happening? We tried hard to find better news out there.

headline.main: Oh, Look, More Glimmers of Good News

byline.original: By STEVEN LEE MYERS, DENISE GRADY, DAVID E. SANGER, ERIC WILSON, KATE TAYLOR and AMY HARMON

docs.lead_paragraph: Yes, the cap seemed to have at least temporarily helped. Still, times are dreary -- in the economy, in the national mood, overseas. Isn't anything positive happening? We tried hard to find better news out there. A Clear Route to Mecca
docs.snippet: Yes, the cap seemed to have at least temporarily helped. Still, times are dreary -- in the economy, in the national mood, overseas. Isn't anything positive happening? We tried hard to find better news out there.     A Clear Route to Mecca

headline.seo: In New York, Getting Thin by Riding the Subway
headline.print_headline: Getting Slim Just by Riding The Subway
headline.main: Getting Slim Just by Riding the Subway

docs.lead_paragraph: Good news for New Yorkers: A study points to public transit’s role in staving off obesity.
docs.snippet: Good news for New Yorkers: A study points to public transit’s role in staving off obesity.

headline.seo: F.D.A. Panel Votes Against Obesity Drug Qnexa From Vivus
headline.print_headline: F.D.A. Panel Votes Against Obesity Drug
headline.main: F.D.A. Panel Votes Against Obesity Drug

docs.lead_paragraph: The advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration voted 10 to 6 that the safety concerns about Qnexa, from Vivus, overrode the potential benefits.
docs.snippet: The advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration voted 10 to 6 that the safety concerns about Qnexa, from Vivus, overrode the potential benefits.

docs.abstract: An advisory committee voted 9 to 7 against recommending a drug to combat obesity.
docs.lead_paragraph: An advisory committee voted narrowly against approval of what could be the first new drug for obesity in more than a decade.
docs.snippet: An advisory committee voted 9 to 7 against recommending a drug to combat obesity.

docs.abstract: Can foods fight lung cancer? Are there cancer risks in the home? Dr. Derek Raghavan of the Cleveland Clinic answers readers' questions about lung cancer.
docs.lead_paragraph: If you stop smoking, does your increased cancer risk eventually return to zero? Can eating carrots protect against lung cancer? Should a recovering cancer patient test for radon, and are there other risks to be aware of in the home? Is there an estrogen-lung cancer link? These are among the questions readers recently posed by readers of the Consults blog. Dr. Derek Raghavan, director of the Taussig Cancer Institute at the Cleveland Clinic, responds.
docs.snippet: Can foods fight lung cancer? Are there cancer risks in the home? Dr. Derek Raghavan of the Cleveland Clinic answers readers' questions about lung cancer.
